text: - [Instructor] Hello, everyone.

In this video, we will take
a look at the new feature,
which provides enhanced observability
for your container workloads

running on Amazon Elastic
Container Service, which is ECS.
This new capability will help reduce

your mean time to detect
and mean time to repair
for your overall applications,
thereby preventing issues

that could negatively
impact your user experience.
Now let's take a look at this new feature
by going to CloudWatch Console

and selecting Container
Insights from the left pane.

Now select ECS from the
dropdown list presented.

You will be presented with
a Performance Summary page,
starting with a honeycomb view

describing the performance
summary of clusters.
As you can see,

there are color grading
here for different clusters,
and these color gradings define
if a cluster is in alarm state

based on your defined
thresholds and alerts.

This alarm state is
resembled by red color.
And if there are no alarms,
it is resembled by green color.

Let's say there's an issue
in one of my clusters.
I can hover to see the alarm details
by looking at different layers,

starting from cluster, going
down to container level.
The darker shade of blue

represents a cluster
having high utilization,
whereas a lighter shade of blue

represents a cluster
having lower utilization.
This page also has sections
stating the performance summaries
of top resource-consuming clusters,
services, containers, and tasks.
Now I would like to explore further,

so I select my cluster from
the Clusters Overview section.
This redirects me

to the container insights
detailed dashboard view.
Here you can see the hierarchy
going down until containers layer.
When you select Cluster,

it provides an overview
of resource utilization
across the entire cluster.
Similarly, when you select Services,
you can see the visualization of metrics
at the individual service level.
And when you select Tasks,

it focuses on task-level
metrics, as you can see,
for different performance thresholds
like CPU utilization, memory utilization,
network storage, et cetera.
And, finally, when you select Containers,

it drills down into
the utilization metrics
for individual containers.

These different views
allows narrowing down
to find the root cause

from cluster, to service,
to task, to container.

Another useful feature
is the Filters option,

which helps you conduct
more thorough investigations
across services, tasks, and containers.
On top of using AWS X-Ray traces,

you can investigate another
two types of logs here,
starting with application logs,
which gives you detailed insights

into the application behavior
within the container.

And it helps you raise
the sequence of events
that led to any issues.
And, second, you can use performance logs,

which are structured logs
containing metric data,
that is, to drill down
and identify container-level root causes.

Now let's look further
into the performance logs.
As you can see, you will be redirected

to the CloudWatch Log
Insights page, as seen here.

Here you can see that the log
group is selected by default

as well as the timeline
is selected as well.

And also there's a sample
query already provided.
Now, running this query
returns to cluster performance log data,
and, in the log message,

you can see each value of
performance metric, right?

Container CPU utilization,
container CPU utilized,
and all these performance-related metrics.
